original_title: Sri Lankan stocks marginally gain amidst low trading activity
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stocks edged up at close on thin trade volumes ahead of the New Year holidays, as investors slowed down activity, an analyst said.

“This week, trade is affected by the long weekend for the Sinhalese and Tamil New Year, which has firms closed and on holiday, so not much interest has sparked in investing,” said Ranjan Ranatunga of First Capital Holdings.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) was up 0.04 percent or 4.05 points to 9,407.64, the highest since March 24.
The most liquid index, S&P SL20, was down 0.55 percent or 15.18 points to 2,754.40.
“The market is flat and weak, and trading volumes were also low,” said Ranatunga.
Pre-pandemic market hours were reintroduced from Monday onwards, and Ranatunga said it was bringing back some positive sentiment to the market.

Sri Lanka’s Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said the country would not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and would engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary “optimization.”
Some domestic debt restructuring discussions have been scheduled for April 20, and investors are likely to wait for further clarity before investing.
Top gainers for the day were Sampath Bank, Hatton National Bank, and DFCC Bank.
Investors in the banking sector are taking a wait-and-see approach until more clarity is given on local debt restructuring.
Shares in Expolanka, Vallibel One, and John Keells Holdings were down due to selling pressures and profit-taking.
The market saw a net foreign outflow of 16 million rupees, and the total offshore outflows recorded so far in 2023 are 3.4 billion rupees. (Colombo/April12/2023)
